lines.text: I hear Japs are happy to die for their emperor. A lot of them are going to be made very happy.

[Tom Adams has just been chided for mistaking a common seabird for an incoming bomber while he was on lookout watch; this forced the 'Copperfin' to make a needless emergency dive]
That's all right, son. I'd rather submerge for one hundred birds, than NOT submerge for one plane.

[Relieved]
Thank you, sir.
There was a democratic movement in Japan after the last war. What happened?
The leaders were assassinated.
Well, what about the people?
They have no voice now. Starvation is the big stick, isn't it, Raymond?
That's right, sir. The big wage is seven dollars a week. They have no unions, no free press... nothing.
They do what they're told.
I'm afraid most of them believe what they're told - like that "hero" who knifed your torpedo man. They've been sold a swindle, and they accept it.
But how can they support such big families on seven bucks a week?
They don't. Daughters of the poor are often sold to factories, or... worse - when they're about 12.
Females are useful there only to work or to have children. The Japs don't understand the love we have for our women. They don't even have a word for it in their language.
How come they picked you?
I don't know. Strong arm, strong back, weak mind!
There's lots of Mikes dying right now. And a lot more Mikes will die. Until we wipe out a system that puts daggers in the hands of five-year-old children.

[during a depth charge attack]
Captain, I'm no good.
Why's that?
I'm scared stiff.
How do you think the rest of us feel?
You're not scared. I've looked at your faces.
I've looked at yours, too. It's the same as the others.
You're scared?
I'll say I am. And so is everybody else.

[Just having come aboard the 'Copperfin']
Uh... How do I get below, sir? I... I've never been aboard a submarine before.

[Slightly bemused, as he points to the only obvious entry into the submarine]
There's the hatch. It goes 'down.'
How'd you happen to volunteer for the submarine service, Captain?

[Coyly]
Well, when I was a kid, I used to get a kick outta' swimming underwater.

[passing out Christmas presents, reading the labels]
'For Pills, the Pharmacist's Mate, a mournful knell; he dropped his vitamins down the periscope well!'
[all hands laugh]
'The new kid forward is wiser but sadder... since he stepped on the skipper coming down the ladder!'
Hey, I apologized!
[more laughter]
'On Wolf's grave a wreath is laid, since he tangled his line with that chambermaid!'
[more laughter as Wolf opens his present]

[pulling out a skimpy nightie]
Aww, you shoulda had it filled!
'All hands get ready to upchuck this dinner; with Cookie in the galley, we're gonna get thinner.'
[pauses amid the laughter, acting offended]

Now listen! If that ain't a new high for gratitude... Who practically mothers all the guys on this ship? I do. Who bends over a hot stove all day long for you guys? I do. Who's gonna get all the glory when you sink a Jap ship? You, that's who! Who's gonna get all the medals out of this war? You guys! And what am I gonna get? Nothin' but varicose veins, and dishwatered hands! Yeah!
Don't take any wooden Yen!

[Tommy Adams is starting look-out duty]
Keep your eyes peeled Kid... we're *nobody's* friend! Even our *own* ships'll shoot *first* and ask questions *later*!
Congratulations, Wolf.
On what?
It's been an hour since anything reminded you of a dame.
You ever want to be a real doctor, Pills?
Yeah... I was one of those college wise-guys who didn't know where he was going. Funny place to find out, on submarines.
What college did you go to?
California. Only a year. Then I signed up. I had an "A" in chemistry... so they made me a Pharmacists Mate.

[Holding up the fuse mechanism of the Japanese bomb that Adams just defused]
Got "Made in USA" stamped on it. The appeasers' "contribution" to the war effort.

[Hands it to the cook]
Take it and stew it, Cookie.
Pills, do you think prayers do any good?
Yes, they do. I *know* they do.
Christoforo Colombo! Here comes a flattop, with a destroyer screen.
We're lying off the Japanese mainland... Thought you'd like to know.

[Attempting to sneak into heavily-guarded Tokyo harbor by concealing the sub under a warship overhead]
Can we hug the cruiser any closer?
We're just about kissing her now, sir.

[Ponders the situation for a second]
If we kiss her bottom, we get an "ash can" right down our neck.

[the 'Copperfin' has torpedoed, but not yet sunk, a Japanese carrier]
Take her *under* the carrier - we'll finish the job with the sting from our tail.

[During a particularly fierce depth-charging of the 'Copperfin']
Would any of you fellas be interested in a 1938 motor scooter?

[During a particularly fierce depth-charging of the 'Copperfin']
I wonder how the invasion of Europe is getting along?

[He and Tin Can have been forced to physically subdue Dakota, who's losing his grip during a particularly fierce depth-charging of the 'Copperfin']
Sorry I had to sock ya'.
It was either your chin, or the boat, Dakota. There was nothing else we could do. We gotta' take it. We can't win if we can't take it. Don't you know that?

[as the USS Copperfin, returning from its perilous mission, transits beneath the Golden Gate Bridge, inbound for San Francisco]
Hey Eddie, ya' think that sub saw any action?

[Dismissively]
Nah... Probably just out for a couple of practice dives.

To the United States Navy, our thanks for making this picture possible. To the gallant officers and men of the silent service, to our submarines on war patrol in hostile waters, good luck, and... good hunting!
